questions.q: What are the four components of a computer system?
questions.explanation: A computer system is divided into hardware (CPU, memory), the OS (controls hardware), applications (word processors, etc.), and the people or machines using it.
questions.answer: Hardware, operating system, application programs, and users

questions.q: Provide at least three resources the operating system allocates.
questions.explanation: The OS acts as a resource allocator, managing hardware and software needs to ensure efficiency.
questions.answer: CPU time, memory space, and file storage

questions.q: What is the common name used to refer to the operating system program?
questions.explanation: The kernel is the one program running at all times on the computer.

questions.q: What do mobile operating systems often include in addition to the core kernel?
questions.explanation: Middleware is a set of software frameworks that provide additional services to application developers.

questions.q: What is an interrupt?
questions.explanation: Interrupts signal the CPU to stop its current task and handle a specific event, like I/O completion.
questions.answer: A hardware signal to the CPU that an event has occurred

questions.q: What special operation triggers a software interrupt?
questions.explanation: A system call is a request by a user program for the OS to perform a specific task.

questions.q: What is one advantage of using a solid state disk over a magnetic disk?
questions.explanation: SSDs are faster because they have no moving parts, unlike traditional spinning magnetic disks.

questions.q: What is the difference between volatile and nonvolatile storage?
questions.explanation: RAM is volatile, while hard drives and SSDs are nonvolatile.
questions.answer: Volatile loses data when power is off; nonvolatile retains it

questions.q: What is another term for multiprocessor system?
questions.explanation: These systems have two or more CPUs in close communication sharing resources.

questions.q: Provide at least two advantages of multiprocessor systems.
questions.explanation: More processors do more work in less time, and if one fails, others can take over.

questions.q: True or False? The most common multiple-processor system uses asymmetric multiprocessing.
questions.explanation: False.  Symmetric multiprocessing (SMP) is the most common, where each processor performs all tasks.

questions.q: What is the name of a multiprocessor system that uses multiple computing cores?
questions.explanation: Multicore systems put multiple CPUs on a single chip.

questions.q: How does a clustered system differ from a multicore system?
questions.explanation: While multicore is on one chip, clustered systems are usually independent computers connected via a network.
questions.answer: Clusters consist of two or more individual systems joined together

questions.q: How does multiprogramming increase CPU utilization?
questions.explanation: If one job has to wait (like for I/O), the CPU simply switches to another job.
questions.answer: By keeping several jobs in memory so the CPU always has work

questions.q: What is the term for a program that has been loaded and is executing?
questions.explanation: A program is passive; a process is active.

questions.q: What part of the operating system makes the decision with regards to which job will run?
questions.explanation: The scheduler picks which process in memory gets to use the CPU next.

questions.q: What are the two separate modes of operation?
questions.explanation: These modes protect the system from errors caused by user programs.

questions.q: What is the mode of the system at boot time?
questions.explanation: The system starts in kernel mode to initialize hardware before switching to user mode.

questions.q: What is the mode of the system when the operating system gains control?
questions.explanation: Whenever an interrupt or trap occurs, the hardware switches to kernel mode.

questions.q: What is the mode of the system when a user program is running?
questions.explanation: User programs run in user mode to prevent them from executing dangerous hardware instructions.

questions.q: Name at least two activities the operating system is responsible for in connection with process management.
questions.explanation: The OS manages the lifecycle and execution order of all active tasks.

questions.q: Name at least two activities the operating system is responsible for in connection with memory management.
questions.explanation: The OS must decide which processes get memory and ensure they don't overwrite each other.
questions.answer: Allocating/deallocating space and tracking used memory

questions.q: True or False? Managing files is one of the most visible aspects of an operating system.
questions.explanation: True.  Users interact with the file system daily to save and organize data.

questions.q: Name at least two activities the operating system is responsible for in connection with file management.
questions.explanation: The OS provides a logical view of storage and handles the actual writing to disks.
questions.answer: Creating/deleting files and mapping files to physical storage

questions.q: Name at least two activities the operating system is responsible for in connection with disk management.
questions.explanation: The OS manages how data is placed on the physical disk to improve performance.

questions.q: Rank these from fastest to slowest: (1) main memory, (2) magnetic disk, (3) registers, (4) solid state disk, (5) cache.
questions.explanation: Registers are inside the CPU (fastest), followed by Cache, Main Memory (RAM), SSDs, and Magnetic Disks (slowest).

questions.q: What is the difference between protection and security?
questions.explanation: Protection is internal management;  Security is broader defense against threats like viruses or hackers.
questions.answer: Protection controls access to resources; Security defends against external/internal attacks

questions.q: List at least four common kernel data structures.
questions.explanation: The kernel uses these standard structures to organize data like process lists or file systems.

questions.q: True or False? A bitmap of length N can be used to represent the status of 2^N items.
questions.explanation: False.  A bitmap of length N represents exactly N items, where each bit is 0 or 1.

questions.q: List at least five different types of computing environments.
questions.explanation: Computing has evolved from desktop setups to mobile, network-based, and virtualized cloud systems.
questions.answer: Traditional, Mobile, Distributed, Cloud, and Real-time

questions.q: Provide an example of an open source operating system.
questions.explanation: Linux is the most prominent OS where the source code is freely available for anyone to modify.
